title: Scrutiny on referees increases as Anthony Taylor and Kevin Friend perform poorly just DAYS after Marbella stag do
text:
Scrutiny on referees increases as Anthony Taylor and Kevin Friend perform poorly just DAYS after Marbella stag do Taylor and Friend delivered poor officiating displays in their respective top-flight matches on Saturday Share Kevin Friend, right, and Anthony Taylor, left, had days to forget on Saturday (Photo: 2017 Getty Images) Share Get football updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! The quality of refereeing in the Premier League is under the spotlight again after a couple of poor officiating displays on Saturday. 
Kevin Friend was the man in the middle at Old Trafford for the 1-1 lunchtime draw between Manchester United and Bournemouth and received widespread criticism for his performance. 
He failed to show red cards to Tyrone Mings and Zlatan Ibrahimovic for separate incidents involving each other, while Andrew Surman was arguably harshly given his marching orders. 
Mings appeared to stand on Ibrahimovic's head in the first half before the Swede exacted retribution with an elbow just minutes later. 
Both men are now facing retrospective action after Friend failed to spot the two incidents. Read More Andrew Surman was shown a red card by referee Friend at Old Trafford... (Photo: Man Utd via Getty) ... while Zlatan Ibrahimovic and Tyron Mings were spared what looked like more obvious dismissals (Photo: REUTERS) 
Meanwhile at the Liberty Stadium later in the day, Anthony Taylor was equally poor during Swansea's 3-2 win over Burnley. 
He awarded Burnley a penalty for handball - despite replays showing Burnley striker Sam Vokes was the only player to touch the ball with his hand in the Swansea penalty area. 
Swans striker Fernando Llorente's headed winner in injury-time was also contentious, with Clarets manager Sean Dyche claiming it should've been disallowed because the Spaniard was gaining leverage by jumping on defender Ben Mee. 
The pair of poor displays came just hours after a report in The Times claimed a number of top-flight referees were in Marbella last week for Taylor's three-day stag do. Anthony Taylor wrongly awarded Burnley a penalty against Swansea (Photo: Getty) The top-flight official was on a stag do in Marbella last week (Photo: Ben Hoskins) 
A number of high-profile refs were given last weekend off or handed lower league games to take charge of before jetting off to Spain last Saturday night. 
In his post-match press conference Burnley boss Dyche revealed he had no complaints about Taylor's midweek trip to Marbella. 
Dyche said: "He's human isn't he? Is there a rule that you're not allowed to do that? He's a human being, he's allowed to live his life I'd imagine, unless there's a rule that prevents him from doing that. 
"As long as he stayed off the carbs because there's no carbs before Marbs!" Like us on Facebook
